document_title: Finger tenosynovitis: Causes, symptoms, treatment, prevention
subsection_content:
Finger flexor tenosynovitis is classified into 3 levels of disease. Specifically includes: (2)
Level 1: Tendonitis, causing local pain; Level 2: The pain feels worse but the finger can still be flexed and stretched; Level 3: The finger is stuck in a bent position, the patient must use the opposite hand to return to the original position. In addition, in many cases the finger becomes stiff in a straight position and cannot be bent (spring finger).

Finger flexor tenosynovitis is classified into 3 levels of disease. Specifically includes: (2)
Level 1: Tendonitis, causing local pain; Level 2: The pain feels worse but the finger can still be flexed and stretched; Level 3: The finger is stuck in a bent position, the patient must use the opposite hand to return to the original position. In addition, in many cases the finger becomes stiff in a straight position and cannot be bent (spring finger).
